description:
Bombyx mandarina, commonly known as the Chinese oak silkworm or Manchurian wild silkworm, is a species of moth belonging to the family Bombycidae. It is the wild ancestor of the domesticated silkworm, Bombyx mori, which is widely used in the production of silk.

Bombyx mandarina is native to East Asia, primarily found in China, Japan, and Korea. It is a medium-sized moth with a wingspan of around 40-60 millimeters. The adults have greyish-brown wings with distinct patterns, and the larvae, or caterpillars, are pale green in color with a distinct horn-like structure on the rear end.

The larvae of Bombyx mandarina feed primarily on the leaves of oak trees, such as the Chinese oak (Quercus mongolica) and the Japanese oak (Quercus serrata). Unlike the domesticated silkworm, the larvae of the wild species are able to spin silk cocoons, but the silk is generally coarser and less suitable for commercial use.

Bombyx mandarina is an important species in the study of the evolutionary origins and domestication of the silkworm, as well as in the understanding of the ecological relationships between insects and their host plants. It continues to be a subject of research in fields such as genetics, ecology, and conservation biology.
